I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Government  of  the  Cook  Islands  plans  to  strengthen  infrastructure  sector 
governance, build capacity, and improve financial and operational management of assets. The 
Government has requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide technical assistance 
(TA). A Fact-Finding Mission in June 2008 held discussions with the Ministry of Finance and 
Economic Management (MFEM), the Public Services Commission, the Office of the Prime 
Minister (OPM), and the Cook Islands Investment Corporation (CIIC) on objectives and scope, 
implementation arrangements, and cost of the proposed TA. This report reflects ADB’s findings 
and  the  understandings  reached  with  the  Government  on  the  TA’s  design,  costs,  and 
implementation arrangements. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.1 
 
2.  The  Government  sought  ADB  support  for  capacity  development  for  improved 
infrastructure services delivery in the sectors of transport and communications, water sanitation 
and solid waste management, government buildings, and energy. The TA was requested to 
support the following actions: (i) changing institutional arrangements and developing capacity 
within  a  comprehensive  infrastructure  governance framework  (IGF)  for  delivering effective, 
efficient, and sustainable infrastructure services; and (ii) policy development and implementation 
for (a) cost recovery and tariff setting, including appropriate provision for community services 
obligations; (b) developing planning and investment criteria and processes for assessing and 
prioritizing  infrastructure  investment  proposals;  (c)  asset  management,  including  systems 
development, asset management planning, performance monitoring, and annual auditing; and 
(d) developing appropriate relationships and roles for public and private sectors while facilitating 
private sector participation in infrastructure services delivery. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
A.  Deteriorating and Poorly Managed Physical Infrastructure 
3.  While  the  Government  has  successfully  pursued  prudent  fiscal  policies  that  have 
enabled it to repay past loans and create loan reserves, it has done so at the expense of 
infrastructure maintenance and investment. This has resulted in aging systems that do not 
provide an appropriate level of service to meet current demand or support future private sector-
led growth. Infrastructure, and particularly on Aitutaki and Rarotonga, is not adequate for the 
expanding  tourism  and  associated  industries  upon  which  the  economy  depends.  The 
Government intends to upgrade public infrastructure countrywide under the ADB-financed 20-
year infrastructure master plan,2 and there is a concomitant need to ensure that both existing 
and new  services  are  efficiently  managed  and  maintained.  ADB  will  support  upgrading of 
infrastructure and has approved a loan3 for the upgrading of the Avatiu Port. Further support is 
planned for upgrading of infrastructure in the water and sanitation sectors. 
 
4.  A  number  of  infrastructure  development  plans  and  policy  prescriptions  have  been 
developed over the past 20 years. Many have failed to achieve their expected impacts because 
of the absence of an agreed and effective IGF that delivers cooperative and coordinated action 
among the central and line ministries. In the past, there has been a degree of rivalry between

individual line departments, overlapping efforts, and some resistance to efforts by the central

5.  In response, the Government commenced a wide-ranging review of the IGF, which will 
be supported by the TA. The Audit Office completed a review of the management functions, 
operational outputs, and systems of the Ministry of Works (MOW) in April 2008. It had far-
reaching recommendations for reforming the MOW and infrastructure sector. In May 2008, the 
cabinet established (i) the National Sustainable Development Commission reporting directly to 
the cabinet, and (ii) an infrastructure committee attached to the CIIC.4 The National Sustainable 
Development  Commission  will  review all projects and align  them  with  the  priorities of  the 
National Sustainable  Development  Plan.  Infrastructure  projects  will  then  be passed  to  the 
infrastructure committee to approve allocations for works funded by the Government and by aid. 
In November 2008, the MOW and the Office of the Minister for Outer Islands were merged to 
form the Ministry of Outer Islands and Infrastructure Planning (MOIP). 
 
B.  Institutional Arrangements and Capacity Issues 
6.  The  dispersal  of  activities  among  different  government  agencies  has  resulted  in 
fragmented and overlapping decision making, ineffective monitoring, and dilution of capacity 
and specialization. These issues are raised in the National Sustainable Development Plan, the 
Audit  Office’s  report  on  MOW,  and  the  so-called  Eggelton  report.5 The  consequences  of 
fragmentation  include  (i)  poor  cooperation  between  agencies  and  poor  compliance  with 
Government policies and procedures; (ii) excessive bureaucracy and misaligned objectives; (iii) 
uncoordinated and reactive work programs and planning; (iv) budgets with little relevance to 
need  or  justification  for  expenditures;  (v)  an  absence  of  measurable  outcomes  linked  to 
programs and budgets; (vi) poor management accountability and erosion of public confidence in 
agency capabilities; and (vii) no clear ownership of policies, and a lack of planning or regulation 
of standards at the national level. 
 
7.  While  the  essential  public  services are  assigned  to  Government-owned  enterprises 
operating under CIIC as the trustee for Crown assets, fragmentation remains for the municipal 
services (roads, water supply, sanitation, solid waste management, and, to a lesser degree, 
regulatory  services  associated  with building  control  and electrical  wiring  and  installations). 
Moreover, there are differences in how these services are provided on the Outer Islands and on 
Rarotonga. 
 
8.  Capacity gaps and outmoded attitudes are undermining infrastructure operations, cost 
recovery, the quality of service delivery (which suffers from poor operational and maintenance 
efficiency and little or no investment planning and asset management), and environmental 
sustainability – vital to maintaining the contribution of tourism to the economy. Lacking are a 
sound commercial orientation and customer-oriented service. There are many current examples 
of  the  consequences,  including  extended  delays  in  adopting  and  enforcing  environmental 
regulations  and  in  enacting  a  commercial  approach  for  operating  the  waste  management 
facilities (which has been official policy since 2001).

C.  Policy Development and Implementation Issues 
9.  Cost  Recovery  and  Tariff  Setting. While people accept paying for electricity and 
telecommunications, there is historical and cultural resistance to the charging of fees for water 
supply,  sanitation, and  solid  waste disposal.  Projects for  improving these  services  involve 
significant capital and operating investments, the costs for which must be recovered either from 
users or through tax revenue. In the latter case, users are not faced with the true costs and 
have no incentive to conserve an increasingly scarce resource. 
 
10.  Service standards have not been established in some sectors, and users have little say 
as to the levels of service provided. There is little accountability for the present tariff levels and 
tariff setting. A tacit expectation exists that commercial enterprises delivering infrastructure 
services will perform some noncommercial activities or community service obligations (CSOs), 
but there are no mechanisms in place to separately identify and recognize these or to provide 
government compensation on an agreed performance basis. 
 
11.  Infrastructure  Planning  and  Prioritization.  The  Government  lacks  a  consistent 
methodology for prioritizing and programming infrastructure development projects. Prior TA has 
developed methodologies that aim to take account of the Government’s economic and social 
development objectives (footnote 2). These have now been agreed and institutionalized within 
the Government planning agencies and national planning process so that harmonized methods 
and criteria are adopted by all the infrastructure subsector agencies and are also observed by 
most of the Government’s development partners. 
 
12.  Asset Management. Poor management and inadequate investment in maintenance and 
rehabilitation has resulted in aging and failing physical infrastructure both on the main island of 
Rarotonga and on the Outer Islands. Infrastructure is failing to meet current demand or to 
support the Government’s objective of private sector-led growth. There is an urgent need for 
infrastructure asset management plans with a medium-term planning horizon. 
 
13.  Private  and  Public  Sector  Roles  and  Relationships.  Maximizing  private  sector 
participation  in  the  construction,  operation,  and  maintenance of  infrastructure  will  result  in 
increased efficiencies and improved and more sustainable levels of services. Services such as 
the collection of household refuse, trenching for cables (for Te Aponga Uira, Rarotonga’s power 
supplier), and trenching for water mains on Rarotonga (MOW) have been outsourced with some 
success, thus avoiding the need for Government investment in plant and equipment. 
 
14.  The Government intends to confine its role in infrastructure to (i) strategic planning and 
policy, (ii) determining affordable service levels in consultation with the users of the service, (iii) 
establishing  programs  for  infrastructure  maintenance  and  operations,  and  (iv)  providing 
appropriate levels of funding. The role of the private sector will be in contracted infrastructure 
construction, maintenance, service delivery, and outsourced professional services. This will 
require new skills and capacity development in both the public and private sectors, but the 
greater need will be in the public sector. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
15.  The expected impact of the TA will be effective delivery of environmentally sustainable 
infrastructure  and  infrastructure  services.  The  expected  outcome  of  the  TA  will  be  an

4   
established governance framework supporting infrastructure management and development. 
This will be characterized by common processes for developing infrastructure investment plans, 
effective and efficient financial and operational management of assets, appropriate opportunities 
for private sector participation, customer-oriented service delivery, and transparent accounting 
and recognition for CSOs. The TA will complement ADB's on-going support for improvements to 
public infrastructure. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
16.  Institutional Improvements and Reforms. Reorganization of the infrastructure sector 
will consolidate resources and overcome fragmentation, assign clear accountabilities, eliminate 
overlap in roles, and establish a platform for private sector participation in physical works and 
service delivery. The TA will assist the Government to combine the technical capabilities and 
staff resources from MOW and the Office of the Minister of Island Administration into a single 
new ministry focused on infrastructure planning, project development, and asset management. 
Water supply and sanitation on Rarotonga—extending later to Aitutaki—will be consolidated into 
a stand-alone water board. TA for stakeholder consultation, change management, capacity 
building, and institutional strengthening will be provided to the reformed agencies. 
 
17.  The TA will prepare plans for detailed change management and implementation of the 
government  agency  reforms,  including  review  of  the  legal  framework  and  requirements, 
development of organizational structures, revisions to financial and operational management 
information  systems  and  key  staff  job  descriptions,  preparation  of  business  plans,  and 
development of performance monitoring and reporting procedures. 
 
18.  Planning and Investment for Infrastructure. The TA will provide two planning and 
policy specialists in the transport and municipal infrastructure sectors to assist with building 
central planning and policy capacity in the OPM and with preparing detailed sector policy 
statements for (i) roads, maritime, and aviation; (ii) energy; and (iii) water supply, sanitation, and 
solid  waste  management.  The  Government’s  CSOs  in  each  of  these  sectors  will  be 
transparently identified and costed. The TA will review the roles of the infrastructure committee 
and national sustainable development committee in the context of the overall IGF, and it will 
recommend measures to ensure transparency and efficiency. 
 
19.  Asset  Management.  The  TA  will  assist  the  Government  to  introduce  a  regulatory 
requirement for asset management plans and annual auditing by the Audit Office that will be 
harmonized  to  the  absorptive  capacity  of  the  affected  agencies.  The  plans  will  cover 
infrastructure planning, maintenance, performance targets, levels and standards of service, and 
public consultation. TA from asset management and organizational specialists will be provided 
to the Cook Islands Audit Office to develop a standard plan template, prepare guidelines for 
plan preparation, and identify minimum criteria, as well as to CIIC for improving corporate 
governance relating to its asset management functions. Assistance will be provided to the line 
ministries  and  other  infrastructure  agencies  in  developing  asset  management  plans  for 
Rarotonga and the Outer Islands. 
 
20.  Private Sector Development. The TA will also assist MOIP and other agencies to 
develop performance-based contracts for outsourcing professional services and for contracting 
in maintenance, rehabilitation, and construction activities from the private sector. Assistance will 
be given to line ministries and infrastructure agencies for organizing and conducting focused 
workshops to impart the new requirements to the private sector consultant and contractor 
industries.

5 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
21.  The total cost of the TA is $666,000. It will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan 
Special  Fund,  funded  by  Government  of  Japan,  in  the  amount  of  $600,000.  Government 
counterpart support will be provided in the form of office accommodation and remuneration of 
counterpart staff in the value of $66,000. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
22.  The MFEM will be the Executing Agency for the TA. The TA will be implemented over a 
period  of  2  years  from  October  2009  until  September  2011,  with  intermittent  inputs  from 
international consultants and support from national consultants. The international consultants 
will be based within the Government agencies that are presently the main subjects of the 
assistance, these being the OPM, Aid Management Division of MFEM, CIIC, and MOIP. They 
will also work with the Government-owned commercial enterprises of the Cook Islands Ports 
Authority, Cook Islands Airport Authority, Te Aponga Uira, and Aitutaki Power Supply. 
 
23.  International  consultant  inputs  (18  person-months)  will  be  required  in  the  areas  of 
institutional  management  (3  person-months),  asset  management  (2  person-months),  urban 
planning and policy (3.5 person-months) transport planning and policy (3.5 person-months), 
legal  specialist  (2  person-months),  and  legal  draftsperson  (4  person-months).  National 
consultant inputs (6 person-months) will be required in the areas of stakeholder consultation 
and  social  analysis  (2  person-months)  and  policy  research  assistance  (4  person-months). 
Terms  of  reference  for  consulting  services  are  provided  in  Appendix  3.  An  international 
consulting firm will be engaged by ADB to provide the services using quality- and cost-based 
selection procedures in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as 
amended from time to time). Disbursements under the TA will be in accordance with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook.6  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
 
the Government of the Cook Islands for Infrastructure Services Delivery Improvement, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

A.  General Description of Consulting Services 
1.  Overview of Assignments 
Consultant services will comprise four integrated components: (i) support for preparing and 
drafting national policies for the infrastructure services; (ii) initial asset management advice for 
(a) support to the Cook Island Audit Office for developing guidelines and basic criteria for 
preparing asset management plans, and (b) support to Cook Islands Investment Corporation 
(CIIC) for developing a property management and asset management and maintenance system; 
(iii) stakeholder consultation and analysis, institutional strengthening, and capacity building to 
assist in establishing the new infrastructure ministry and water board; and (iv) support for the 
legislation to put into effect the reform of the sector.

2.  Component 1: Development of National Policies 
Will  provide  for  the  preparation  of  consolidated  policy  documents  for  transport  (maritime, 
aviation,  and  roads),  water  supply,  sanitation,  solid  waste  management,  and  government 
community service obligation (CSO) policy to guide the integrated planning and development of 
infrastructure. 
 
3.  Component 2: Asset Management Guidelines and Criteria and Support to 
CIIC for Property Asset Management 
Will assist the Cook Islands Audit Office to adopt a standard template for infrastructure asset 
management plans and determine base criteria for accepting asset management plans. The 
standard template and criteria will be reviewed as sector-specific asset management plans are 
being drafted. Assistance will also be provided to CIIC in assessing needs for maintenance and 
renewal of government properties throughout the Cook Islands, identifying criteria for annual 
audits, and developing an integrated property (asset) management database. Procedures will 
be developed for annual building fitness certification.  
 
4.  Component 3: Capacity Building and Institutional Strengthening 
Will provide management, organizational, institutional, and financial advice and guidance to 
heads of the new infrastructure ministry and water board through the change process while 
establishing the new agencies. Assistance will include surveys and analysis of stakeholders’ 
(including resource owners’) attitudes on the changes. 
 
5.  Component 4: Legal Support for Sector Reform 
Will  provide  support to  the  Crown Law  Office for  drafting  legislation  to amend  the  Public 
Expenditure Review Committee and Audit Act and provide for mandatory asset management 
plans and regulation of these by annual audit. The support will also involve preparing legislation 
to establish the new agencies and rescind outdated statutes. The support will extend to drafting 
regulations  necessary  for  operating  the  new  agencies,  including  regulations  governing 
application and adjustment of tariffs and arrangements for implementing and accounting for 
CSOs. 
 
B.  Detailed Terms of Reference 
1.  Component 1: National Policy Development 
1.  The  tasks  of  the  international  transport  planner  and  policy  specialist  (team  leader, 
component 1) shall include the following: 
(i)  Work within the Office of the Prime Minister (OPM) and liaise with its chief of staff 
on all aspects of the assignment, keeping the chief of staff fully advised of 
progress and matters requiring OPM involvement or resolution.

Appendix 3  11 
(ii)  Review the roles of the infrastructure and the national sustainable development 
committees in the context of the overall infrastructure governance framework, 
and recommend measures to ensure transparency and efficiency. 
(iii)  In close liaison with the secretary of transport, work with Ministry of Transport 
staff  in  developing  a  transport  policy  statement  and  gaining  the  Ministry’s 
commitment and ownership of the process and policy. 
(iv)  Consult with the Government’s development partners and all sector stakeholders 
on the integration of key externally funded infrastructure programs and local 
stakeholder  needs.  Organize  and  conduct  individual  and  interest-group 
discussions,  stakeholder forums,  and  workshops  to engage  with, and obtain 
shared input from, the diverse groups reliant upon the transport sector. 
(v)  Research,  analyze,  and  assimilate  all  relevant  background  information  and 
reports. Incorporate the aims, objectives, and outcomes desired of the National 
Sustainable Development Plan and summarize all key stakeholder concerns for 
inclusion  in  the  policy  statement.  Assist  OPM  and  the  municipal  (urban) 
infrastructure  and  policy  specialist  to  interpret,  analyze,  and  document 
government CSO policy. 
(vi)  Draft the transport policy document in consultation with OPM and the Ministry of 
Transport while duly regarding their subsequent ownership of the policy; their 
understanding  of  local  issues,  political  nuances,  and  acceptability  of  policy 
statements;  and  the  need  for  the  cabinet’s  endorsement  of  the  policy. 
Appendices will be presented in a concise format sufficient to support or explain 
the policy. Assist OPM and the Ministry to present the document for the cabinet’s 
endorsement. 
(vii)  Provide advice to OPM, Te Aponga Uira, Aitutaki Power Supply Co., the Office of 
the Minister of Island Administration, and others as required for the development 
of  national  policy  for  power  generation  and  distribution  and  a  national 
telecommunications policy. 
 
2.  The  international  municipal  (urban)  infrastructure  and  policy  specialist’s  tasks  shall 
include the following: 
(i)  Support the transport planner and policy specialist by coordinating inputs and 
managing inputs from the national policy research analyst. 
(ii)  Develop a template for a succinct policy document for water supply, sanitation, 
solid waste management, and the government CSO policy. 
(iii)  Assist in organizing consultation and sector workshops with donor partners and 
sector stakeholders similarly to the tasks outlined in terms of reference (ii) and (iii) 
for the transport policy specialist. 
(iv)  Draft the policy documents in consultation with OPM and the Ministry of Works 
(MOW) while duly regarding their subsequent ownership of the policies; their 
understanding  of  local  issues,  political  nuances,  and  acceptability  of  policy 
statements; and the need for endorsement of the policies by the stakeholders 
and  cabinet.  Appendixes  will  be  presented  in  a  concise  format  sufficient  to 
support or explain the policy. 
(v)  Assist  OPM  and  MOW  to  present  the  policy  documents  to  the  cabinet  for 
endorsement. 
 
3.  Reporting to the transport planner and policy specialist, the national policy research 
analyst shall support the international consultants in carrying out policy research and analysis 
and in preparing and drafting the policy documents.

12  Appendix 3 
2.  Component 2: Asset Management and Support 
4.  The international asset management specialist’s tasks shall include the following: 
(i)  Work with the Audit Office in all aspects of the assignment and keep the director 
of audit advised of progress and matters requiring Audit Office involvement or 
resolution.  Liaise  with  government  infrastructure  agencies  and  the  Island 
Administrations on Aitutaki and the Outer Islands. 
(ii)  Analyze all relevant documents pertaining to asset management and work with 
the Audit Office to assess the present state of asset management in the Cook 
Islands. Present recommendations on the structure for asset management plans, 
consistent with the limited resources available in the Cook Islands. 
(iii)  Recommend  the  basic  criteria  for  Audit  Office  acceptance.  Determine  and 
specify the requirements of 10-year minimum programmed needs and related 
budgets. 
(iv)  Prepare in consultation with the Audit Office a template and guidelines for the 
preparation of asset management plans and the minimum criteria required to 
satisfy subsequent audit by the Audit Office. 
(v)  Located  within  the  new  infrastructure  ministry,  work  with  the  heads  of  that 
ministry  and  of  the  water  board,  assisting  both  agencies  to  develop  the 
processes and methodologies for preparing integrated asset management plans 
for roads, water supply, sanitation, solid waste management, and other assets 
under their control. 
(vi)  Advise the agencies on the process for data capture and for compliance with the 
base criteria established by the Audit Office. 
(vii)  Build the capacity of the agencies through training seminars, workshops, and on-
the-job instruction. 
(viii)  Leave the agencies with an outline template for each asset management plan, a 
time-bound program for collation and analysis of all asset information and data. 
(ix)  Prepare a detailed analysis of the capacity of each agency to implement their 
respective asset management plans, clearly identifying requirements for further 
technical support. 
 
4.  Component 3: Capacity Building and Institutional Strengthening 
5.  The  international  management  and  institutional  specialist’s  tasks  shall  include  the 
following: 
(i)  Located  within  the  new  infrastructure  ministry,  work  with  the  heads  of  that 
ministry  and  of  the  water  board  to  assist  both  agencies  to  develop  their 
management,  human  resources,  and  financial  capabilities.  Advise  on  the 
organizational  structures  and  institutional  relationships,  and  provide  any 
additional  external  support  required  for  change  management  during  the 
agencies’ establishment period. 
(ii)  Provide  wide-ranging  advice  on  organizational  structure,  development  of  job 
descriptions  and  delegations,  performance-based  service  contracts,  and 
performance-related  reviews.  Present  observations  on  training  and  capacity 
building requirements as well as financial management and reporting needs. 
(iii)  Provide advice on organizational efficiency and effectiveness, as well as on 
commercially oriented operations and outcomes. In the second phase, undertake 
a rigorous internal review of each organization, its institutional arrangements, and 
performance.  Provide  detailed  advice  to  the  senior  officers  for  additional

Appendix 3  13 
refinement  for  improved  operations,  identifying  needs  for  further  technical 
assistance where applicable. 
 
6.  The national social researcher and analyst’s tasks shall include the following: 
(i)  Located within the new infrastructure ministry, work with the heads of the ministry 
and the water board to assist both agencies to undertake social and stakeholder 
surveys to assess willingness to pay for water and sanitation, and modalities for 
involving water resource (catchment) landowners in establishing commercially 
oriented water supply services. 
(ii)  Design and assist with a public information campaign to explain and disseminate 
information  regarding  introduction  of  charges for  water,  sanitation,  and  solid 
waste services. 
 
5.  Component 4: Legal Support 
7.  The legal specialist’s tasks shall include the following: 
(i)  Work  with  the  Cook  Islands  Crown  Law  Office  and  the  legal  draftsperson 
appointed  under  this  component  to  draft  modern  law  establishing  the  new 
infrastructure  ministry  and  the  new  Rarotonga  Water  Supply  and  Sanitation 
Board, advising on the framework and structure for the new legislation. 
(ii)  In consultation with the Crown Law Office, edit and sign off on the final draft 
legislation while providing advice as to the outmoded legislation to be rescinded, 
the associated regulations needed, and the structure and content of these. 
 
8.  The legal draftsperson shall work with the legal specialist and the Crown Law Office in 
drafting the legislation establishing the new infrastructure ministry and the proposed Rarotonga 
Water Supply and Sanitation Board, as well as the associated regulations.
